content.title: ICU Delirium Prevention and Management
content.summary: ICU delirium affects 50-80% of mechanically ventilated patients and is associated with increased mortality, prolonged hospitalization, and long-term cognitive impairment. Prevention is paramount using the ABCDEF bundle: avoiding benzodiazepines, promoting early mobilization, and maintaining sleep hygiene. Assessment uses CAM-ICU or ICDSC. Treatment focuses on addressing underlying causes (infection, metabolic, pain) rather than pharmacologic interventions, as antipsychotics have not shown benefit and carry risks.
key_points: Prevalence: 50-80% of ventilated patients; increases mortality 3-fold
CAM-ICU: Confusion Assessment Method for ICU; gold standard screening
Prevention: ABCDEF bundle, avoid benzodiazepines, early mobility, sleep hygiene
Types: Hyperactive (10%), Hypoactive (50%), Mixed (40%) - hypoactive most missed
Treatment: Address underlying cause; antipsychotics NOT proven beneficial
Long-term: Associated with persistent cognitive impairment for years
content.statement: ICU delirium is a common complication associated with poor outcomes, prevented through the ABCDEF bundle including benzodiazepine avoidance and early mobility, screened with CAM-ICU, and managed by treating underlying causes rather than routine antipsychotics.

explanation.intuition: Delirium is the brain's 'check engine light' - it signals something is wrong but doesn't tell you exactly what. The brain, especially when sick, is sensitive to insults like infection, medications, and sleep deprivation. Rather than suppressing the signal (antipsychotics), we need to fix the underlying problem.
explanation.key_insight: Hypoactive delirium (quiet, withdrawn) is MORE common than hyperactive (agitated) but is often missed because it doesn't cause management problems. It's equally dangerous. This is why routine screening with CAM-ICU every shift is essential.
explanation.technical_details: Delirium pathophysiology involves neuroinflammation, neurotransmitter imbalance (cholinergic deficiency, dopamine excess), blood-brain barrier disruption, and oxidative stress. CAM-ICU assesses: (1) acute onset/fluctuation, (2) inattention, (3) altered level of consciousness OR (4) disorganized thinking. Positive if 1+2+either 3 or 4.

definitions_glossary.delirium: Acute brain dysfunction with altered consciousness, inattention, disorganized thinking
definitions_glossary.CAM_ICU: Confusion Assessment Method for ICU; validated delirium screening tool
definitions_glossary.ICDSC: Intensive Care Delirium Screening Checklist; alternative screening tool
definitions_glossary.hypoactive_delirium: Delirium with lethargy, decreased activity, quiet (50%)
definitions_glossary.ABCDEF_bundle: Evidence-based bundle including sedation, delirium, mobility interventions
definitions_glossary.sundowning: Worsening confusion in evening/night; common in delirium
definitions_glossary.delirium_tremens: Severe alcohol withdrawal with delirium; requires benzodiazepines
definitions_glossary.sleep_fragmentation: Disrupted sleep architecture contributing to delirium
definitions_glossary.early_mobilization: Getting patients out of bed early; reduces delirium duration
definitions_glossary.post_ICU_syndrome: Long-term cognitive, psychological, physical impairment after critical illness

outcomes.cost: Billions of dollars annually in US

predisposing.vulnerability: More risk factors = lower threshold for delirium

features: Attempting to get out of bed
hyperactive.recognition: Usually recognized quickly due to management challenges

hypoactive.recognition: Often MISSED; as harmful as hyperactive

features.fluctuating_course: Waxes and wanes; often worse at night

criteria: Feature 1: Acute onset or fluctuating course
Feature 2: Inattention (squeeze on 'A' in random letter test)
Feature 3: Altered level of consciousness (RASS not 0)
CAM_ICU.frequency: At least every shift; after sedation changes
CAM_ICU.note: Cannot assess if RASS -4 or -5 (too sedated)

ICDSC.advantage: Can be assessed retrospectively over shift

ABCDEF_bundle.A: Assess, prevent, manage pain (uncontrolled pain causes delirium)
ABCDEF_bundle.B: Both SAT & SBT (light sedation reduces delirium)
ABCDEF_bundle.E: Early mobility (out of bed day 1 when possible)

non_pharmacologic.mobility: Early physical therapy; out of bed to chair

address_underlying_cause.approach: Delirium is a symptom; find and treat the cause

antipsychotics.evidence: REDUCE and MIND-USA trials: NO benefit on delirium duration or mortality
antipsychotics.guideline: PADIS 2018: NOT recommended for treatment or prevention
antipsychotics.potential_role: Severe agitation with safety risk (last resort, short-term)

dexmedetomidine.evidence: May shorten delirium in hyperactive patients

safety_measures.fall_prevention: Bed in low position, sitter if needed
safety_measures.avoid_restraints: Associated with worse outcomes; last resort

definition.@value: Prevention and management of acute brain dysfunction in critically ill patients using evidence-based multicomponent strategies

scopeNote.@value: Core ABCDEF bundle component; antipsychotics not proven beneficial

medicalCode.description: Delirium due to known physiological condition

learning_objectives: Apply CAM-ICU to screen for delirium
Differentiate hyperactive, hypoactive, and mixed delirium
Implement ABCDEF bundle for delirium prevention
Identify modifiable risk factors for delirium
Explain why antipsychotics are not first-line treatment
clinical_pearls: Hypoactive delirium (50%) is most common but often missed
Benzodiazepines are the biggest medication risk factor for delirium
Antipsychotics do NOT reduce delirium duration or mortality (REDUCE, MIND-USA trials)
Cannot assess CAM-ICU if RASS -4 or -5 (too sedated)
common_misconceptions: Hyperactive delirium is most common - hypoactive is 5× more common
Antipsychotics treat delirium - evidence shows no benefit
Quiet patient is fine - hypoactive delirium carries same mortality risk

citations.authors: Girard TD, Exline MC, Carson SS, et al.
citations.title: Haloperidol and Ziprasidone for Treatment of Delirium in Critical Illness

evidence.confidence_rationale: High-quality RCTs (MIND-USA, REDUCE) and PADIS guidelines inform management
